title: Pinterest Harnesses AI for Visual-Based Shopping
text:
Pinterest Inc. wants to redesign how people shop online for the perfect area rug or pair of shoes.

The company is leveraging its artificial-intelligence technology, fed by billions of images, to entice more users into buying items they see on its website or mobile app—and to expand its user base, which would translate into more advertising dollars.

Billing itself as a “visual discovery engine,” the company offers a website and mobile app where its 300 million global monthly active users can browse through photos and post—or “pin”—them to personalized digital inspiration boards. Users look to Pinterest for images related to style, gardening, home décor and other categories.

The company said this week that its AI technology can accurately identify more than 2.5 billion objects in photos of fashion and home décor, such as a specific brand of men’s black boots or a particular brown leather sofa. Hundreds of millions of those objects are “shoppable,” meaning users can click on an item—or a similar recommendation—and purchase it through a brand’s website. Pinterest doesn’t get a cut from the brand if the user makes a purchase; it makes money through ads on its platforms.

For example, users looking for inspiration for fall décor can find a photo of a front door that includes wreaths and pumpkins and pin it to a board. They can zoom in on particular aspects of that image, such as a pumpkin or wreath, through a feature on the company’s mobile app and website called Lens, powered by AI. The technology can automatically identify the object, provide a link to retailers that sell it and show photos of similar items that can be purchased. The technology also works with photos that users upload themselves.

Pinterest, founded in 2010, beefed up its object-recognition technology with the acquisition of VisualGraph in 2014. The company’s AI algorithms have gradually improved, in part because of more than 200 billion photos, or “pins,” that people have uploaded to the site over nearly a decade, said Jeremy King, the company’s new head of engineering.

Jeremy King, Pinterest's head of engineering Photo: Pinterest Inc.

“When you’re building something that’s based on machine learning or computer-vision technology, what you need is a giant corpus of data,” said Mr. King, a former Walmart Inc. technology executive who joined Pinterest about six months ago ahead of its initial public offering. “Pinterest is the master of that.”

“People come to Pinterest with shopping intent, and oftentimes in the past they had to leave Pinterest to go find the item,” Mr. King said. “Now, we’re making it easier to get to the retailer.”

The technology could be critical to Pinterest’s monetization strategy, said Andrew Lipsman, principal analyst at market-research company eMarketer. Traditionally, it has been difficult for advertisers on Pinterest to truly understand the link between an impression, or a user’s view of a pin, and their purchase behavior, Mr. Lipsman said.

Because Pinterest can identify more objects within a photo, it can show more recommendations for users to purchase. That direct link could be critical in helping advertisers better understand their return on investment. Pinterest “is one of the most interesting marketing and advertising plays…but at the same time, they have a lot to prove,” Mr. Lipsman said.

The company is up against competition from Alphabet Inc. ’s Google, which has recently ramped up efforts in online shopping, and Facebook Inc. ’s Instagram. Facebook earlier this year said it acquired visual shopping and AI startup GrokStyle Inc.

Pinterest reported revenue of $261.2 million for the quarter ending June 30, up 62% from a year earlier. Its global average revenue per user was 88 cents, up 29%. The company posted a net loss of $1.16 billion, weighed down by costs associated with its IPO.

The company spends “a tremendous amount of effort” scraping brands’ websites to make sure the products it is recommending to users for purchase are in stock, Mr. King said. The eventual goal is to give users the ability to purchase any object in any photo by linking to the brand’s website, he said.

Pinterest depends on Amazon.com Inc. ’s cloud service, Amazon Web Services, for the vast majority of its computing and storage capabilities. Its AI-based visual-search engine is built by in-house software engineers as opposed to relying on cloud-based AI tools.

Mr. King reports to Pinterest’s Chief Executive Ben Silbermann, who spoke about the focus of getting users “from inspiration to action” in the company’s most recent earnings call. Letting users purchase products they discover through the application is an “essential” value proposition for both customers and advertisers, which will lead to an independent revenue stream in the long run, Mr. Silbermann said, without specifying when.

Q&A with Jeremy King Jeremy King surprised the retail industry earlier this year when he announced he was leaving Walmart Inc., where he drove a number of initiatives as its U.S. chief technology officer, for Pinterest Inc. We talked with Mr. King about the factors that drove his departure and what he wants to do next. Q: Why did you decide to leave Walmart?

A: I had done a run there, almost eight years. We’re empty-nesting and wanted to move back to San Francisco [from another part of the Bay Area]....And I felt I had rebuilt both the e-commerce platform and a big chunk of the stores’ platform already so it wasn’t like there was a million new things to do. It seemed like a good time.

A: The intent was to take a year off [from Walmart] and decide what to do next. I got introduced to Ben [Silbermann, CEO of Pinterest] and had a great conversation with him about not only the technical challenges but the road ahead and the capabilities there. A: I think the challenges here are all digital [commerce], whereas some of the ones at Walmart were more physical [commerce]. Here, I’m spending more time on just the ability to effectively take our platforms and scale them up by 10 or 20 [times]....Also, Walmart was very siloed. I was in charge of the U.S. business and Pinterest is very much a global platform.

A: People think of us as a social network and we’re really not. We’re a discovery engine. People come to Pinterest for themselves.
